ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about standard practices in engineering communication, both oral and verbal. In my actual independent study, I learned about formulating problems in a tractable but non-trivial way.

You learn a lot of soft skills such as presentation and public speaking as well as advice for a career in engineering. The final presentations was a great opportunity to showcase what you accomplished in the semester.
I learned how the design method works, and as a result, am able to conceive of the challenges and the solutions that underlie the problem I am trying to solve.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: well directed and organized 
Weakness: not pivoted toward individual projects
Small setting and quite personalized.  A good way to learn the research and design method in a tight-knit community.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: This is a great course to take if you want to explore a mechanical engineering topic more deeply. I learned a lot by working closely with my advisor, and I much preferred it to some of my intermediate engineering courses.
Great course for independent project research.
Yes if you have a personal project and want to work on it during the semester/want to get research for credit and understand how to do research in mechanical engineering.
